abstract.para: This document describes how to get started writing documents for the MapServer Documentation Project (MDP).

sect2.title: Purpose and Scope of This Document
sect2.para: This document is intended get you up-to-speed with how to write MapServer documentation. It will briefly discuss the preferred format for MDP documents as well as tools that can be used to create and process MDP documents. It will also give an overview of how to get started writing and submit what you have written.

Although a brief introduction to DocBook and XML are provided, this document is not meant to provide a complete guide to creating DocBook XML documents. Instead, it will direct you to other resources available on the web.

sect2.title: The MDP
sect2.para: The MapServer Documentation Project is a collaborative effort to provide free, high-quality documentation for MapServer software. The project is being coordinated by the TerraSIP project at the University of Minnesota Department of Forest Resources, but the actual writing will be done by volunteers from the MapServer user community. MapServer users are invited to share their knowledge.

The MDP will follow the Linux Documentation Project model with the goal of creating a set of task-specific HOWTO documents and a smaller set of Guides to be used as syntactic references. The MDP will accept documents written with the DocBook DTD, preferably DocBook XML version 4.1.2. If you choose to write documents using an SGML version of the, please keep them xml compliant (see XML vs. SGML). Important documents may be accepted in other formats to be converted by a volunteer from the MDP.
Documentation will be made available through the MapServer web site at http://mapserver.gis.umn.edu/doc.html

sect2.title: Why DocBook XML
sect2.para: DocBook provides for more than just formatting. Free software packages, such as Saxon and Xalan, transform DocBook XML into other formats. With these tools you can automatically build indexes, table of contents, and links within or without the document. Several editors are available that help you to write DocBook XML. In the end, DocBook is more concerned about defining the elements of a document than how they will be formatted in the end; stylesheets take care of that. This distinction will help you write faster since you don't have to worry about placement of paragraphs, font sizes, font types, and so on.

sect2.title: The MDP DocBook XML to HTML Transformer
sect2.para: A MDP Transformer is available to preview DocBook XML documents without downloading any additional software. It uploads a local XML file, transforms it with the DocBook XSL stylesheets and Saxon, and outputs an HTML version of the file. If you use this tool you will not need the XSL stylesheets and XML processing tools listed below. You will, however, need the DocBook DTD for your XML editor.

sect2.title: The DocBook DTD
sect2.para: The DocBook XML DTD is available from http://www.docbook.org/xml/4.1.2/. The DTD defines the tags and structure of a DocBook document.

sect2.title: XSL Stylesheets
sect2.para: The latest version of the DocBook XSL stylesheets (currently 1.29) is available from http://nwalsh.com/docbook/xsl/. The stylesheets specify the look and feel of your document when it is transformed to other formats. There are stylesheets for several output formats including html and formatted output (used to create printable documents). We will be using the basic html/docbook.xsl for short documents and html/chunk.xsl for long documents.

sect2.title: XML Processing Tools
sect2.para: I have used two, free Java-based processing tools for XML transformation to HTML. Saxon is available from http://users.iclway.co.uk/mhkay/saxon/. This seems to be quite a popular tool right now for use with DocBook XML with XSL stylesheets. I was able to download a simplified version (Instant-Saxon) and get it running on a Windows-NT machine in about fifteen minutes. One nice feature of Saxon is that it identifies errors in a document and outputs the error with the line number on which it was found.

Xalan is part of the Apache XML project. It is available from
http://xml.apache.org/xalan-j/. Xalan is also quite popular within the DocBook XML community. It can be integrated with other Apache XML tools including one that produces PDF documents.

sect2.title: XML Editing Tools
sect2.para:
There are now quite a few tools available for editing XML ranging from WYSIWYG tool to extensions to traditional command-line editors. XED is a free GUI tool that reads your DTD and provides menus for element and attribute entries. Emacs users should consider psgmls. Nedit is a basic text editor with sgml/xml syntax highlighting that runs on UNIX systems. I have also heard good things about the XML Spy; a free 30-day evaluation version is available from the homepage.
A list of SGML editing, tools from the Linux Documentation Project's Author Guide by Jorge Godoy and David Merrill.
A review of some editors from ivritype.
A more complete list of tools from xml.com.

sect2.title: CVS
sect2.para:
MDP documents will be controlled through a Concurrent Version System (CVS). There are several advantages to using a CVS:
CVS will keep an off-site backup of your documents. This also provides a way to exchange a document under development by several authors.
CVS can integrate changes from several authors working on a document at the same time.
CVS keeps a log of what changes have been made to a document and allows retrieval of old versions.
If you are new to CVS, there are some good references available through the CVS home page.
For access to the MDP CVS, contact the documentation coordinator at mdp@lists.gis.umn.edu.

sect2.title: The MDP XML template
sect2.para: The MDP HOWTO Template in HTML and DocBook XML gives you a document skeleton (to download the XML file right click on the link and select "Save Link As...").

sect2.title: Choosing a Topic
sect2.para: You may choose any topic for which documentation is needed or choose a topic from the current projects list. The idea is to focus on HOWTOs, so choose a clearly-defined topic that is not too narrow and not to broad. Also make sure your topic is undocumented. When you have chosen a topic, let the documentation coordinator mdp@lists.gis.umn.edu know what you are working on. Maintaining a current list of what is being written will prevent duplication of effort.

sect2.title: DocBook Tags
sect2.para: For complete documentation "DocBook: The Definitive Guide," by Norm Walsh and Leonard Muellner is available online from http://www.docbook.org/.

There is a useful section in the Linux Documentation Project Author Guide that discusses the most commonly used DocBook markup tags and compatibility between SGML and XML. It can be used as a abbreviated DocBook reference. Note there is a typo in the second paragraph where is recommends keeping you elements in upper case for compatibility with XML. Element and attribute tags should actually be in lower case.

sect2.title: XML versus SGML
sect2.para:
If you are writing with a DocBook SGML DTD it is not difficult to keep the document XML compliant. Some editors, such as psgmls+emacs, do this automatically. There are a few points to keep in mind (as outlined in DocBook: The Definitive Guide).
All elements, attributes, and entity names must be typed in lowercase.
Attribute values must be enclosed in quotes; you may use single or double quotes, but not curly quotes.
Do not use empty elements or any markup minimization and do not omit end tags.
Comments are not allowed inside markup declarations.

sect2.title: Submitting a Document
sect2.para: To submit your new document just add it to the CVS. The document will be edited to ensure a certain amount of uniformity between documents, and an edited version will be posted for your review. When you have given the OK, the new document will be transformed to HTML and added to the MapServer documentation page.

sect2.title: Mailing Lists
sect2.para:
Several MapServer mailing list are available. Issues such as documentation format and documentation needed are discussed on the MapServer Docs list. To subscribe, send an email message to majordomo@lists.gis.umn.edu containing two lines:
subscribe mapserver-docs END
A confirmation message will be sent to you to which you must respond before you will actually be added to the list.

To unsubscribe, send a message to majordomo@lists.gis.umn.edu containing two lines:
unsubscribe mapserver-docs END

The mapserver-users listserv was created as a means for MapServer users and developers to exchange application ideas, discuss potential software improvements, and ask questions. A searchable archive of the mapserver-users list is available.

sect2.title: Other Writing References
sect2.para: For tips on writing, check out the Style Guide from the Linux Documentation Project's Author Guide.

sect1.title: Translating to Other Languages
sect1.para: Translation of MapServer Documentation to other languages is encouraged. The translated documents will be stored in the CVS in the same branch as other documents with an extension the indicate which language it is in. The two-letter extension is determined by the ISO-639 standard. For example, a spanish translation of getstarted-howto.xml will be stored as get-started-howto_es.xml.

The translator will be specified in the document with the "othercredit" tag within the "articleinfo" as shown in the example below:
<othercredit> <contrib>Translation:</contrib> <firstname>Jamie</firstname> <surname>Smedsmo</surname> <affiliation> <orgname>University of Minnesota</orgname> <orgdiv>TerraSIP Project</orgdiv> <address> <email>jsmedsmo@gis.umn.edu</email> </address> </affiliation> </othercredit>
